facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 901 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 901 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1039 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1039 of 1954.

facts.text: Respondents brought a suit in the court of the Second Munsif, Burdwan for declaration of entitlement to property, confirmation of possession, permanent injunction against appellant, or delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents brought a suit in the companyrt of the Second Munsif, Burdwan for a declaration that they were entitled to the property in dispute, for companyfirmation of their possession thereof and for a permanent injunction

facts.text: Property in dispute belonged to Jatindra Mohan Hajra, father of three of the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondents was that the property in dispute belonged to one Jatindra Mohan Hajra, who was the father of three of the respondents.

facts.text: Jatindra Mohan Hajra mortgaged the property to Kali Krishna Chandra, who was a defendant in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: He mortgaged the property to Kali Krishna Chandra who was a defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Kali Krishna Chandra obtained a mortgage decree in the Court of the Subordinate Judge Burdwan.

anchor.surface_text: Kali Krishna Chandra obtained a mortgage decree in the Court of the Subordinate Judge Burdwan and in execution of the said decree got the mortgaged property sold,

facts.text: In execution of the mortgage decree, the mortgaged property was sold in auction and purchased by Kali Krishna Chandra, who came into possession in November 1937.

anchor.surface_text: purchased the property in auction sale and thus came into possession thereof in November 1937.

facts.text: Kali Krishna Chandra sold the property to the present appellant in June 1942.

anchor.surface_text: the meantime it appears that Kali Krishna Chandra sold the property to the present appellant in June 1942.

facts.text: Respondents applied under S. 37-A of the Act after its introduction and obtained possession of the property in November 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After the introduction of S. 37-A in the Act, the respondents applied thereunder for getting back possession of the property. ... The respondents succeeded in their application under s. 37-A of the Act and obtained possession

facts.text: Appellant disturbed respondents' possession, leading to a criminal case which resulted in acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case further was that their possession was disturbed by the appellant thereafter and they had to go to the criminal companyrt in that companynection. But the criminal case resulted in acquittal

facts.text: Munsif decreed the suit in favour of respondents, holding S. 37-A applies to bona fide transferee for value.

anchor.surface_text: Holding that s. 37-A applied to bona fide transferees for value also, the Munsif decreed the suit.

facts.text: Jurisdiction issue not raised before Munsif.

anchor.surface_text: But the question of jurisdiction of the Board on the ground that the amount involved was more than Rs. 5,000 was number raised before the Munsif

facts.text: Subordinate Judge overruled jurisdiction objection holding amount was Rs. 4,044/8/-, but held S. 37-A does not apply to bona fide transferee, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: That objection was however over-ruled by the Subordinate Judge on the ground that the amount involved was only Rs. 4,044/8/-. But the Subordinate Judge seems to have held that a bona fide transferee for value cannot be affected

facts.text: High Court held Board had jurisdiction as debt Rs. 4,044/8/-, S. 37-A applies to bona fide transferees, restored Munsif's decree.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of jurisdiction the High Court held that the amount of debt involved was only Rs. 4,044/8/- and therefore the Board had jurisdiction. On the question whether bona fide transferees for value were bound, the High Court

facts.text: Application under S. 37-A showed decretal dues as Rs. 5,841.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged in this companynection that the very application made by the respondents under S. 37-A shows that the amount of decretal dues was Rs. 5,841

facts.text: Debt amount disputed: Rs. 5,841 (decretal dues) vs Rs. 4,044/8/- (held by courts).

anchor.surface_text: the amount of decretal dues was Rs. 5,841 and therefore the Board had numberjurisdiction.

facts.text: Supreme Court held jurisdiction point not raised in trial court (Munsif), so not entertained; respondents could have shown Collector sanction if debt over Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this point as to jurisdiction should have been raised at the earliest possible stage in the Munsifs companyrt and as it was number so raised it should number have been permitted to be raised

facts.text: S. 37-A introduced by Bengal Agricultural Debtors Amendment Act, 1942, No. 11 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: This happened before S. 37-A was introduced in the Act by the Bengal Agricultural Debtors  Amendment  Act, 1942,  No. 11 of 1942 .

facts.text: Property sold after August 12, 1935 in execution of decree.

anchor.surface_text: where any immovable property of such person had been sold after August 12, 1935 in execution of a decree of a civil companyrt

facts.text: Property was in possession of decree-holder on or after December 20, 1939, or alienated by decree-holder before that date in specified manners.

anchor.surface_text: c  if the property sold was in the possession of the decree-holder on or after the twentieth day of December 1939 or was alienated by the decree-holder before that date

facts.text: Alienation by decree-holder (Kali to appellant) was after December 20, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The present alienation was by the decree-holder after December 20, 1939 and therefore the appellant cannot say that she is number companyered by s. 37-A

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court decision that S. 37-A applies to bona fide transferees.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that persons like the appellant were companyered by S. 37-A of the Act. The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

facts.text: Rule 144 under the Act limits Board jurisdiction to Rs. 5,000, proviso up to Rs. 25,000 with Collector sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 144, framed under the Act, which relates to jurisdiction of the Board, provides that the maximum amount of the sum total of all debts due from a debtor which can be dealt with under the provisions of Act shall be Rs. 5,000.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1039 of 1954.
raises a question as to the interpretation of S. 37-A of the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act, No. VII of 1936  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

concepts.interpretation: Applies to bona fide transferees for value; 'any person' in sub-s (8) includes such transferees; sale set aside leads to ejectment of possessors except under-riayats; reading sub-s (8) with (1)(c); alienation after Dec 20, 1939 not excepted.

anchor.surface_text: The debtor may present a copy of the award made under sub-section  5  to the Civil Court or Certificate officer at whose order the property was sold, and such Court or Certificate-officer shall thereupon direct that the sale be set aside, that the debtor together with any person who was in possession of the property sold or any part thereof at the time of delivery of possession of such property to the decree-holder as an under- raiyat of the debtor and who has been ejected therefrom by reason of such sale be restored to possession of the property with effect from the first day of Baisakh next following or the first day of Kartic next following, whichever is earlier, and that any person who is in possession of the property other than a person who was in possession of the property or part thereof as an under-raiyat of the debtor at the time of delivery of possession of such property to the decree- holder shall be ejected therefrom with effect from that date.

concepts.interpretation: 'Any person' in possession (except under-riayat) to be ejected upon setting aside sale; includes bona fide transferees.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 144, framed under the Act, which relates to jurisdiction of the Board, provides that the maximum amount of the sum total of all debts due from a debtor which can be dealt with under the provisions of Act shall be Rs. 5,000. There is however a proviso to this rule to the effect that with the previous sanction in writing of the Collector, a Board may deal with an application if the sum total of all debts due from the debtors exceeds Rs. 5,000 but does number exceed Rs. 25,000.

concepts.interpretation: Board jurisdiction up to Rs.5000 ordinarily; up to Rs.25000 with Collector sanction.

Therefore if any party wishes to urge that the Board had numberjurisdiction because the amount of the debt was over Rs. 5,000, it must urge it in the trial companyrt in order to give an opportunity to the other party to show that even if the amount due was over Rs. 5,000 the sanction of the Collector had been obtained by the Board.

holdings.text: The contention as to jurisdiction of the Debt Settlement Board is rejected because the point was not raised in the trial court (Munsif's court).

anchor.surface_text: We therefore reject the contention as to jurisdiction on the ground that the point was not taken in the trial court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objection to jurisdiction under Rule 144 should be raised at earliest stage in trial court to allow other party opportunity to show Collector sanction under proviso; not raised before Munsif, hence waived.

holdings.text: Section 37-A of the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act applies to bona fide transferees for value from the auction purchaser/decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that persons like the appellant were covered by S. 37-A of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide language 'any person' in sub-s(8) mandates ejectment of possessors upon sale set aside; no excluding proviso for bona fide transferees; inclusive definition of decree-holder; harmonious construction with sub-s(1)(c); alienation after Dec 20, 1939 not excepted; ameliorative purpose of Act.

holdings.text: The words 'any person' in S.37-A(8) are of wide import and include bona fide transferee for value who is liable to ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: The words any person used in s. 37-A 8  are of very wide import and would include even a bona fide transferee for value of the property sold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading; effect of setting aside sale nullifies derivative possession rights; no legislative intent to limit relief only where decree-holder remains in possession.

holdings.text: Upon setting aside the sale under S.37-A(8), any person in possession (other than specified under-riayat) shall be ejected, including auction purchaser or subsequent transferees.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that where a sale is set aside, whoever may have purchased the property in the sale whether the decree-holder himself or somebody else-will have to give up possession,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Imperative direction to set aside sale and eject possessors; right to possession derives from sale which ceases to exist; applies to auction-purchaser and their alienees.

holdings.text: There is no specific provision excluding bona fide purchasers for value other than the decree-holder-auction-purchaser from the purview of S.37-A(8).

anchor.surface_text: If the intention had been that a bona fide purchaser for value other than the decree-holder-auction-purchaser would be out of the purview of s. 37-A (8),

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of proviso or exception despite clumsy drafting; intention clear from wide language and structure.

holdings.text: S.37-A(12) provides inclusive definition of 'decree-holder' extending to transferees by assignment or operation of law.

anchor.surface_text: Decree-holder is defined in s. 37-A 12  as under - In this section the expression decree- holder includes the certificate-holder and any person to whom any interest

holdings.text: Under S.37-A(1)(c), application maintainable if property in decree-holder possession on/after Dec 20, 1939 or alienated before that date except specified bona fide transfers; post-1939 alienations fully covered.

anchor.surface_text: The present alienation was by the decree-holder after December 20, 1939 and therefore the appellant cannot say that she is not covered by s. 37-A

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditions precedent satisfied here as alienation in June 1942 after Dec 20, 1939; no exception applies.

holdings.text: Harmonious reading of S.37-A(8) with (1)(c): once sale set aside, alienees from decree-holder liable to ejectment unless falling within pre-Dec 20, 1939 exceptions in (1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Reading therefore the wide language used in S. 37-A 8  with s. 37-A  1   c , it is clear that once the sale is set aside, even alienees from the decree- holder

holdings.reasoning_summary: Integrates wide ejectment language with applicability conditions; supports coverage of post-1939 transferees.
